Award.AwardTitle: ARTS: Revising Ceraphronoidea (Hymenoptera), a possible link between sawflies and apocritan wasps
Award.AbstractNarration:
Ceraphronoidea are small, under-studied parasitoid wasps whose larvae feed on and eventually kill other insects. Many species of Ceraphronoidea are important in biological pest control programs in agricultural systems. Ceraphronoidea also appear to be the missing link that is critical for our understanding of the evolution of Hymenoptera, a lineage of insects represented by more than a million species (10% of all organisms). This project will result in broadly accessible resources that lift barriers to future research on these insects, including: a phylogeny based on molecular and anatomical data, a revised higher-level classification, images of specimens, data for tens of thousands of specimens, species-level monographs for agriculturally-relevant groups, and robust tools that use molecular and anatomical data for identification of species.

The project will also test a novel approach for describing species. This new method increases the openness and accessibility of biodiversity data and allows one to do analyses of color, texture, shape, and other phenotypes in order to look for ecological patterns and to assist in diagnosing species. The approach is broadly applicable and stands to connect data from taxonomic treatments of any organism, a first for taxonomy. A workshop in contemporary morphology methods will facilitate training and dissemination of this new approach. Two graduate students will be trained as integrative systematists and experts of Ceraphronoidea, the first in over a decade.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ceraphronoidea is comprised of two extant families of parasitoid wasps, Ceraphronidae and Megaspilidae, that are abundant in many habitats worldwide. At the start of this project about 600 species were known, but diagnostic tools existed only for certain Old World taxa, and the taxon had no active experts. The lack of expertise was surprising, given how easy it is to find these wasps and also how several species are known to negatively impact managed biological control programs. Aphanogmus dictynna (Waterston, 1923) (Ceraphronidae), for example, is a parasitoid of multiple wasps that are used to control the coffee berry borer beetle, a major pest of coffee beans. This ARTS project aimed to remove barriers that inhibited research on Ceraphronoidea, by (a) training a new generation of experts, who know the biology of this lineage and who have skills to produce useful taxonomic treatments; (b) estimating relationships between ceraphronoid genera in order to (minimally) revise the higher classification and make it predictive; (c) generating descriptive, morphological data (phenotypes) in a way that make them available for computation and reasoning; (d) revising multiple ceraphronoid faunas using contemporary taxonomic approaches.

The intellectual merits of this project are diverse, as the tools needed to scale up research on this lineage, and to inform evolutionary research on related Hymenoptera, were substantially enhanced. The Conostigmus fauna (Megaspilidae) of North America was revised, as were the Megaspilidae of Madagascar, Trassedia of the world, Aphanogmus of North America, and fossil Ceraphronoidea. Taxon concepts for these wasps are now more clearly defined and illustrated, and these species can be more readily identified. Each taxonomic treatment was also annotated using phenotype-relevant ontologies and a structured syntax (Web Ontology Language), so that trait data can be reasoned over. These phenotype annotation sets serve as important tests for the viability of this approach to species description and its potential value over traditional, natural language descriptions. The project also yielded a higher-level phylogeny, which sheds light on the family- and subfamily-level classification (which seem to be robust) and highlights some aspects of the genus-level classification that require future work.

The impacts of this project are broad and span beyond the facilitation of research on this phylogenetically relevant and biologically interesting lineage of Hymenoptera. Three students were intensively trained in Ceraphronoidea taxonomy. Dozens of students, attending at least five different institutions, were trained in the use of ontologies for phenotype representation and also in emerging methods of microscopy. Hundreds (at least) of non-experts learned about the importance of species discovery, descriptive taxonomy, and the thousands of species that remain to be named, even from their own backyards.
